div.p: D3141 Letters to Sir Henry Ayers from Baron von Mueller 1873, State Library of South Australia, Adelaide.

Let me assure you, dear Sir Henry, that I am fully sensible of the generosity shown by yourself and your honorable colleagues towards Mr Giles; and let me beg of you to express my best thanks for the liberal support also to the other members of your Ministry.
The SA Government had decided to contribute£250 towardsErnestGiles's new expedition.
I am convinced, that Mr Giles will acquit himself creditably also on this occasion, but we must not expect too much, as disasters may befal the party, however cautious the small band may be, and as the country is sure to be widely inhospitable in its present state, altho' the discovery of minerals and the dissemination of good fodder herbs and grasses will render
every square mile
of your whole territory sooner or later available for settlement.

Mr Giles has had from me or rather through me now £350.- .- for
this
expedition, a small part of which I have advanced myself, so as to give him no delay, it being important that he should be at Mount Olga
Now Kata Tjuta, NT.
before the end of April. He thus gets fairly provided this time, indeed far better than the last. As there is space for a dozen expeditions for many years to come, I trust his operations will not lessen the chances of your own explorers. Indeed what value can be an extensive territory to any state, unless it is mapped

The map of Mr Giles's tracks, prepared in Adelaide reflects much credit on your Survey Office. The new plants of this expedition will be published this month in the 59th number of my "Fragmenta phytographiae Australiae."
B73.03.02.In fact, M's descriptions of Giles's plants were not published as a group but were spread across the next few numbers of the Fragmenta.
